Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Precipitation Variability in California from 70 Kyr to 8 Ka: Using High Resolution, Multi-proxy Speleothem Records to Understand Past Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop speleothem paleoclimate records from caves in the Sierra Nevada in California. The researcher, a new Assistant Professor at Vanderbilt University, will produce uranium-series dated records of stable isotopes (oxygen and carbon) and metal/calcium ratios that are sensitive to a variety of climate processes, but particularly precipitation. In addition, the investigator will collaborate with colleagues on evaluating the records using existing NCAR paleoclimate simulations and make an attempt to determine the pathways of the moisture transport to the study area. The study will focus on the time interval beginning in marine isotope stage 3 up to about 8,000 years ago in the Holocene. Thus the records will include the abrupt changes during the deglacial interval 21,000 to 10,000 years ago, the interval that experienced changes in climate associated with ice sheet retreat and changes in the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation.

The project also includes active participation in an educational program for disadvantaged high school students in the Nashville area. The PI will develop interactive classroom materials and host summer research opportunities for students. The PI is a recent Ph. D. embarking on her research career in her first academic position.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The available records of past climate change from archives like lake sediments and tree rings offer a varied picture of how rainfall in western North America changed during and since the last glacial period. Challenges in finding long-lived, continuous, and easily datable records have limited our understanding of the regional response of precipitation in this drought-prone region to large-scale warmings and coolings of the last several thousand years and how this response might vary in space and time. This project addressed this challenge by 1) developing and refining precisely-dated records of precipitation variability from cave deposits sampled from the western Sierra Nevada foothills, California to look in detail at climate change at two time intervals during the last glacial period, and 2) integrating the wide array of published western North American records of precipitation change during the Last Glacial Maximum (21,000 years ago) to examine regional variability in precipitation response and compare this regional array to climate models.

Sierra Nevada cave deposits suggest that warm periods in the Northern Hemisphere that occurred between 55,000 and 67,000 years ago and 8,000 and 19,000 years ago were associated with decreased rainfall in central California, while colder periods during those intervals were associated with increased rainfall. These results are consistent with many other regional climate records that associate warming with drying across the Great Basin and southwestern US.

By compiling an array of regional climate records from the Last Glacial Maximum, we were able to map a pattern of dry conditions in the Pacific Northwest and wet conditions in the southwest separated by a northwest-southeast trending transition zone. Comparing this array with the results of twelve different climate models of the Last Glacial Maximum, revealed that the models that most closely matched this pattern show a stronger winter jet stream that is squeezed and steered in a northwest-southeast trend by high pressure cells. This result reconciles previous observations and hypotheses about how and why precipitation varied in western North America during the height of the last ice age, and can help inform predictions for future changes in rainfall.

Two Metro-Nashville Public School high school students were involved in this research and completed summer research internships at Vanderbilt. One of the students, Jansen Gibson, presented his work at the Geological Society of American annual meeting and was a semi-finalist in the Siemens competition. This research supported an early career female principle investigator and as well as research by several Vanderbilt graduate and undergraduate students.
